Early Access Review
								I've been in love with football management sims since the days of One-Nil[www.myabandonware.com]. That's 1992, my friends.I've never enjoyed one as much as this one.This game is simple enough to play that you can jump right in and start playing. And if you want a casual experience, you can play this game like that. Don't think too much about your decisions, just pick what feels right. You can do that and have fun.Or, if you want a more analytical experience, you can take your time over each decision. You can put your roster into a spreadsheet, plan out which players you will develop and which ones you will sell, and when.You can crunch the numbers over the tactical decisions in the match. Do I take a shot from long range with my ACC 52 midfielder against his DEF 67 keeper, or is it better if I try a layoff pass through his center back to my forward, who can then try to score with a rainbow feint? You can do the math and figure out which one has a better chance at a goal--and also think about what position you leave the opponent with if you do not get a goal.In other words, you can play this game hardcore, and try to make the best decisions all the time (even though many of the decisions will defy exhaustive analysis), or you can play by the seat of your pants, and try to win by instincts. It is a remarkable acheivement to have created a game that can satisfy both types of play styles.You will like this game if you like:Turn-based tactics and strategy. (Even if you aren't a football fan, you will like this aspect, if you like turn-based squad tactics at all.)Roster management--balancing the need to win matches now with the need to develop your next generation of players.Elegant game design--something simple to learn, but deceptively complex beneath the surface. Every decision that confronts you offers enough options to be interesting, but not so many to be overwhelming.The challenge of taking the worst club in the lowest league and slowly building it into a continental champion.Replayability--start over with a new club and try a different strategy.Real club names and logos. It takes only a couple minutes to download the user mods with real names and logos for all of the clubs in all of the leagues. After all, isn't it more fun to take over West Bromwich Albion, with the throstle-on-a-hawthorn-branch logo, than some club named West Bromwich FC represented by a generic green eagle silhoutted atop a soccer ball?Things this game does not do:Pretty graphics. If you want eye candy, look elsewhere."Realistic" simulation. Players have four attributes, there are 10 different special abilities they can learn, and the pitch is a 10x7 grid. It certainly "feels" like football, but it is not a "realistic" simulation.Complex player relations. Players do their best, all the time, no matter what. You don't have to figure out how to motivate them, whom they like to play with, etc.Player contract negotiations. When you acquire a player he has a 1-year contract. When a contract is due to expire you can sign a new contract (1-3 years), let the player go, or sell him. The cost of the new contract depends on the footballer's level at the time of signing and the length of the contract. There's no negotiation.Media interactions. No press conferences, interviews, etc.The threat of getting sacked. It's your team. You make all the decisions, and you never lose your job.As of the date of this writing (April 29 2016), the game still has the Early Access tag, but it is really a complete game.The developers are adding additional features, but there isn't anything missing.

Early Access Review
								Early Access on Steam has a notorious reputation for being a haven for dodgy developers and half-finished alpha prototypes that never make it into a Beta stage of play. Let me assure you: Football Tactics does not fall into this category. This is a game and development team that are doing EA right. But why listen to me? Take a look at the up-to-date demo provided here on the store page; visit the discussion forum to see how often the devs visit, respond and take in feedback; and look at the highly active workshop community - which the devs enjoy highlighting in announcements.This is a game community to rival any AAA title community.The game itself (as of Dec 30, 2016) is a highly polished turn-based strategy game. The demo lets you play a full season with all the bells and whistles, and if you do purchase the game, you can continue your saved game. As of writing I have started season 2 of my NCAA-mod game and I couldn't be happier with the state of play. The mod is brilliant in of itself, and the developers are looking at ways to incorporate even more community ideas based.It may seem like a turn-based strategy and a usually fast-paced sport like football shouldn't go hand-in-hand, but something just works. Somehow it blends well together and provides a challenging and unique take on not one but two genres. Players have unique stats for their positions which can be improved on through training and game-play, there are plenty of leagues incorporated into the game itself, and the newly implemented league editor encourages you to include leagues that may otherwise not be in the base game (like the NCAA). The UI is easy to navigate and lends itself to a simple to read yet still detailed enough management side of the game where you can build your strategy for match day via a formations menu. You can either be hands-on during match day, simulate or watch (and then intervene at your leisure). The AI, in my opinion, is well adjusted for each level of team and league I've played so far. Teams with good defense won't suddenly let you score goals, and you have to change up your tactics to suit your opponent. Gameplay is rewarding in its challenge.Football Tactics, as it stands, is a complete game that offers a refreshing take on the hundreds of other football titles out there. Fancy on building a team that resembles your favourite players, well you can, with the current build featuring a face editor. New features are promised as they come to light, and I think even when this game has left Early Access, we can look forward to many more features and content from the developers and the active community.This is a title that could change the landscape of a rather stagnant sports genre. RTS NFL? Yes please.

								I‚Äôm such a big fan of Sports Interactive‚Äòs Football Manager that when Creoteam approached me to cover their Football Tactics game rather than another game that I was hoping to feature developed by them that I was more than a little skeptical. Nothing is as in depth, serious and addictive in regards to football management games as good old FM. I‚Äôve played many hours in a number of other management games that attempt to push FM off of its porch but nothing has ever come close. I feared that Creoteam‚Äôs game was just going to end up being just another game that tried its best but fell woefully short. Thankfully I was quickly alleviated of my fears when I realized that that wasn‚Äôt what they were attempting to do at all. What their intention to create was a football management game that was much more accessible to all gamers ‚Äì not just football super fans ‚Äì as well as a game that was much more casual and nature and just an overall fun gaming experience.In many ways Football Tactics reminded me of a few of the older shareware football management games that I played in my teenage years. These were games that were nowhere close to the uber tight management games that FM and Out of the Park Baseball are producing today but they were games that I vividly remember sinking tens or even hundreds of hours into.  For a gamer and a sports nut this game has the potential, and already is for its stage of early access, to be a lot of fun. You don‚Äôt need everything to uber serious all of the time so the game is going to fit a very nice niche.The game plays out similarly to turn based combat games do on a grid with the obvious difference being that its football rather than an action-strategy game. Players have various different skills that are what you would expect from a football player with special skills such as shot cannon, lob passes, etc. giving the game some spice and flavor. Games are relatively quick affairs with some players feeling that they‚Äôre a little too short so perhaps an option to extend the game‚Äôs length ‚Äì which many sports titles currently allow ‚Äì perhaps being a nice option to appease them. I‚Äôd also like to see some more options within the game ‚Äì a few more moves added. However, I‚Äôve just been promoted out of the first league so more advanced techniques and skill may start becoming available as I progress during the game.I like the amount of options that have been developed outside of matches themselves. The full gamut of options for a football fan are present. You can play the transfer market ‚Äì buying better players and selling those that have been made redundant. You can also upgrade your club in a number of different ways. You can increase your seating capacity which will in turn increase the amount of money that you take at the gate. Improving your youth academy allows you to get better young footballers into the club. The first scout assistant decreases the age of players on the transfer list while the second scout assistant increases the number of players on the transfer list. Improving your major assistant enables substitutes to get experience after a match and finally positional coaches increase the amount of experience players get following matches.The game is already heavily Steamified with 51 achievements giving hunters something to aim for and there are eleven trading cards to get to collect a full set. Steam Workshop integration has already been added to the game so that players can create mods, leagues and other things to improve the game. Finally, leagues can be played by both a single player or multi player to add a more competitive spirit to the game. In all, I‚Äôm very impressed with the amount of work that has already been completed on the game. The game is feature complete as Creoteam promise but they want to add even more features and tools to the game to make it the best game that it can possibly be and that makes me excited.Although it probably wont replace Football Manager as my go to football management game it is a game that I return to time and again to experience its casual, smart and very well designed and develop footballing experience. 								Well I always really liked the idea of a Football game (soccer in America) and I actually own quite a few of those games.But the problem I always had is the management was more of a headache and a bit too complex, and the actual football game (where you watch/play the game) was a bit too boring and drawn out.This game seems to have found a perfect 'level' of things, at least for me.The management is just the right amount of complexity where you feel like you are managing your team, but not so much complexity that you're too overwhelmed.And the games are engaging as you have to manage your 'tactics' ;) to move the ball around and get a goal, and controlling each player in a turn-based fashion and stuff like this is just satisfying all around.I really look forward to seeing the game grow and develop just a little bit more.(in particular the multiplayer as well as a few little tweaks to the game that are being mentioned on the forums already)For those curious how the actual matches work, there are a number of features and things that make it quite nicely complex, without being overwhelming.Every 'turn' in game is 2 minutes of time that goes by, out of the 45 minutes x2 halves.Each team gets 3 turns in a row, before passing control to the opposing team, you can end your 3-turn segment earlyif you wish.Each player has different skills, accuracy, control, defense, etc.. and these skills come into play, for example, when 'crossing' an opposing player in a match.So for example the opponent player has control of the ball.. and you want to take it from him.So you move your player up adjacent to the opposing player with the ball, using one of your three actions.Then you attempt to 'wrestle' the ball from him.Depending on each of your skill in Control, a dice will be rolled for each player, with a maximum possible roll depending on skill.So for example say the opponent with the ball has a maximum 'potential' roll of 30.Your 'attacking' player has a maximum potential roll of 25.You attempt to wrestle the ball, the dice is rolled (in the background, doesn't actually show the dice) then you roll a 25 (lucky) bu the opponent only rolls a 20.. you are successful at wrestling the ball from him, despite having lower skill.But it was still risky.With your third and last action you kick the ball towards the goal.There are several defense men and the goalie in the way.Each one has a maximum potential to block, and you have your potential to successfully kick.You roll a 20.. then the first defense player rolls a 15, then the second a 7, then the goalie a 17.Then that's it, the ball goes through and YOU SCORE!!!The matches are  engaging, the management is deep but not overly so.The game is just fun, and I can't wait for MP to be added, cause if done right, will make this game just great.Dev's are listening to minor issues, and improvements suggestions on the forums, and are very active.I highly recommend this game if you're looking for a good Football/Soccer experience that's fun and easy to get into,and possibly have been burned by other Football/Soccer games that were just too boring and un-engaging.

Well done Creoteam, really well done. Why is it so good? Because it is simple, yet deep. Easy to grasp, but will take cunning and skill to master. First I spent an hour deciding on my club's name, fiddling with the colours and jerseys, then it plunges you straight into the competition. Only a few tabs, like the team roster with the basic pitch layout and who you want to play where, the training menu with just a couple options for each player, the buying/selling transfers one, the upgrade one and the league table and calendar. Nothing to get lost in, easy to keep all your players in mind and how to best use them in a game.And the game? A brilliantly simple concept.  3 actions per turn when you can try to take the ball from the other team, pass it, dribble or shoot. The skill of your player vs. the skill of the opposing player will determine if you will be successful. But whenever you score a goal, you're genuinely happy, because you executed a tactic perfectly.Even at version 0.2 the game is perfectly playable, the looks and animations are excellent for a simple-graphics game, you'll probably want to turn off the repetitive music after a half an hour, but otherwise it's great fun.

Early Access Review
								The problem with Football Tactics, simply put, is that it lacks depth. At its core this is supposed to be a turn based strategy game, yet it also tries to be as casual as possible. The movement is limited by the small pitch size and the relatively small choice of actions means that you'll be doing the same things over and over again. Since the game is heavily reliant on RNG you will usually have to play the numbers to have a shot at a consistently succesful season, which further limits your influence on the proceedings. Your players will, for large parts of the game, have only one skill and most situations are dictated by a singular attribute, so your decisions usually get simplified even further.Progress mostly comes from player stats, which give the game an RPG~ish touch, yet also seem to be mostly random. You can buy and sell players, but due to the way finances are set up you'll want to grow your own, which mostly means getting decent young players and leveling them up. Upon level up the player gets a semi random set of stat upgrades. Level ups come quite regularly but are usually pretty meager on their own (+1 to your primary stat seems to be the average), which means building up a team to take on the best opposition is a lengthy undertaking.On the plus side these may be things some players look for. There's minimal input on your end and yet, through unnecessarily grindy upgrades, there's some sense of progress (which you will attribute to your skill, even though you know better). I've put quite a few hours into the game while watching Netflix on my primary screen and I have to admit it's a great fit for that. The UI/graphics are simple yet pleasant and while the audio is laughable it's fortunately entirely irrelevant. It isn't punishing at all, there is no fail state and it will reward you just for being there, which I personally fail to appreciate but can still potentially see other people enjoying. Maybe I went in expecting the wrong thing. I read the name as if there was an emphasis on tactics, I thought of great games like Frozen Cortex or even Blood Bowl and while I never expected the game to have that kind of quality, this was stilll a huge let-down. I spent more than ten hours with it hoping for the game to improve towards the late game, but its inherently simple design stops it from ever becoming more than a casual side activity. Early Access Review
								To be clear, this game is fun. And it is possible to beat stronger teams with good tactics. I like the fact that if you study your opposition, look at their players and abilities, you can formulate a strategy to neutralize and even win, even against good teams. If you like strategy games, and football, you will probably enjoy this. Real life concepts, like using players to pull the defensive shape apart and then following on with players moving into the vacated space, work well. But I also feel that the RNG in terms of special abilities favors the AI. My players special skills fail routinely, even at full energy and against weak opposition, while the AI players seem to somehow manage to beat my rolls consistently, even when they have no business doing so. I'm not opposed to challenge, and I understand that it's not supposed to be a walk in the park in the higher divisions. But I do feel like even with perfect tactics, the AI sometimes decides their abilities are going to work, and mine will fail. Matches take between 10 and 20 minutes, which is great for just popping in and out. The tactics setup can be tedious, with lots of clicking through menus to line up your squad properly, but it's not a crippling feature. After a couple seasons, the difficulty ramps up considerably, and you will probably need to grind a couple campaigns just to bring the overall quality of your squad up to par. If you are enjoying the game, this probably won't bother you. But it can be frustrating to consistently run up against teams you simply cannot match up with, no matter your tactical brilliance. Like most games, the more time you put into it, the better you (and your squad) will get. All in all, I definitely recommend this game to football fans, or anyone who likes a simple (yet deeply challenging) strategy game. It's easy to learn, but there is a decent amount of depth in terms of lining up your squad to match up and defeat the oppostion. The devs seem to still be engaged, so perhaps the true 1.0 will be even better. Considering the price (I got it on sale for 11.99 US), this is a good investment.

To be honest, I still have to fully realize the depth of strategical option, since I did about 4 seasons (with 3 different teams), so I haven't tried all the skills yet ... but right now I can only say, strategy in this game is very streamlined and the one best option is easy to identify with no reason I would stop spamming it in hopes of getting more goals. Basically, there's no real "setting up for the goal" since it comes down to getting the ball to the forward, get him as close as possible to the goal and shoot: from there, it's a skill throw for the shot and it's always boiled down to probabilities. I can score through 3 defenders on the other team if they are amateurs ... or it is impossible to score in season 2 against 3rd league teams until I have taken enough losses that my players have leveled up (which isn't the problem for me but a reality in this game).By changing a few mecanics, this title could become a very, very good turn based strategy title with light RPGs elements. But then it would become a lot more time consuming I guess, since they would have to give more actions, make actions harder, passes shorter, having other adjacent allies provide support automatically while having adjacent opposing players provide pressure automatically making actions harder, provide appropirate skills for all new concepts, etc. which would make games longer through the system AND mking you think about each move, to set the best probabilities for your actions.Conclusion: a negative review due to lack of depth in actual match gameplay. For example, the footballers who populate your club‚Äôs lines have only four rated skills:  accuracy for shooting goals, passing to other teammates, defense for taking the ball from your opponents, and control for mainlining possession during an opponent‚Äôs defensive action. However, these four skills, tactics cards, tactics formations, and your players‚Äô age and energy level create on field challenges that are deeper than expected.  The matches are turn-based with each team alternating through 3 actions per side for a set number of actions per half. During one cycle you might have a mid-fielder pass to a forward, the forward dribble to get  a better shot angle, and then the forward make a precision shot on goal. Of course, the opposing team will try to counter your moves each step of the way. Off the field, club mangers can shop the transfer market, direct player training and development, and oversee expansion of the team‚Äôs fan base, coaching staff, and facility upgrades. The business model is easy to understand. The better players perform on the field the higher their price and trade value rises.  Put together a string of victories and your club‚Äôs fan base will grow helping you earn more from ticket sales for home games. In addition to money, your team will also earn prestige points that you can spend on team management decisions.Football Tactics includes stock leagues from around the world in addition to a growing number of national and international leagues that users are adding on Steam Workshop. If you don‚Äôt like your club‚Äôs name, kit, or logo, then you‚Äôre free to modify them in the in-game editor. Also, you can edit the names of team members, too.

The Boy Done WellOf sedentary football technicians there are many, sitting amidst the plush comforts of their immovable habits, while boomingly piping up to the gaffer for that long awaited change. Yet, for ludophiles and enthusiasts, little remains other than to play "Football manager," the lacklustre manager-mode in any reflex-based title, or simply have a go at some 2-bit "Fantasy Football" league somewhere in the dusty corners of the net.But lo-and-behold, when choices seem as meagre as empty mist-wrapped stands, when a hot soup-flask is not enough to warm your cockles, Creoteam come to the rescue with a more than interesting, even palatable, offer. "Football Tactics" is born, underrated hidden gem like Matthew Le Tissier, seemingly casual, at times unexpectedly difficult, always overwhelmingly addictive. "Football Tactics" is worthy of attention, and not only for fans of the game. The game plays out with familiar turn-based mechanics, a system encompassing rules seen in well known titles like Civilisation, X-Com or the recent Wastelands 2, but also adding some specials seen in systems employing the "Active Time Battle" combat. Yes, those are JRPGs more often than not, and this game makes use of abilities and talents in a similar manner.The all-too-familiar compulsion mechanics are there; win games, gain XP, level your footballers. Train one of four stats (Accuracy, Passing, Defense, Control) and mould the style of play which suits you. Play the Guardiola game by controlling the football with high "Control" and "Passing" stats. Or simply hoof the ball upfront with the "Long Pass" skill, and hope your lanky centre forward latches onto it. Want to keep possession? You can "fortify" your striker in the same way you fortify units in Civ, getting a "Control" bonus. Want to dribble past the whole back-four, like Diego did against Belgium? Use "Raibow feint," one of the talents gained by levelling up your footballers.Granted there is still room for improvement here, like additional modes and a beefier, more-complex ruleset. As it stands, the game is breakable simply by upgrading your youth coach, waiting out promotion, farming XP, and building an all-star team which will waltz through the first two or three leagues, like a vintage Omar Sivori. But improvements are being made, and it really does look promising.Overall, amply recommended; among the big rubbish pile that is Early Access, there is a sparkle which gives us hope.

								Kk, I deleted my old review, since I felt it might have been harsh, so here I go again. The verdict is still the same (not recommended, at least at the moment), but I feel I now understand the game well enough to explain my reasons better.All in all, this game shows a lot of potential, and is fun to play, even now. The graphics and music are pretty much "meh!", as in pretty bad, but don't matter anyway, and don't really influence my opinion of the game. What does influence it, is the gameplay mechanics.Basically, this is a stripped-down / casual football manager. It really tries to be and look simple, but here is where I was starting to have problems. The first problem, and perhaps the major one, is that it doesn't really succeed in being simple, at least when it comes being intuitive and understandable. I've clocked countless hours of gameplay on plenty of versions of both football manager games and action soccer games, such as FIFA and Pro Evolution Soccer in the past, so I dare claim to be able to learn such games quick and easy. Not with Football Tactics, though. For a game that presumes to be simple, there sure are quite a lot of reading materials. While some of the skills and moves are easy enough to figure out while playing, others aren't, so don't plan on just jumping in and figuring out as you go.The second problem regarding the game's presumed simple design, is that in some aspects, it is too simple. Soon enough, many things become tedious and tiresome, as the game becomes repetetive and dull. Some would choose the word 'boring'.My last issue with the game is its core gameplay component - how it deals with every action within the soccer games. While I can't provide any proof of any of this, as I don't have access to the game code, I feel very strongly that sometimes, in specific situations, the results don't make sense. I took quite a few games as test cases and explained this in much detail in the forums. I got some answers from the developers, but I still feel that while there's no bias to either side (I'm pretty sure the AI doesn't "cheat"), some results don't make sense. As this game is still on "Early Acess" at the time of writing this review, I dare say that at least in my humble opinion, the AI needs work just as much as any other aspect of the game, if not more.Also, some interactive tutorials would be helpful as well. TL;DR - A promising game, but I suggest waiting for improvements, especially with the AI.

								First things first: I gotta hand it to the devs for including American teams that are either close or spot on in terms of names of the MLS teams.  With a mod you can even get the real names and logos. The game is fun in a sort of "mindless" way and the games go by quickly so it can be addicting to just keep playing one more over and over. Now I have to list the negetives. THIS IS STILL WHEN IT'S IN EARLY ACCESS:1. MY overall experience so far is that the RNG is missing the "random" part. There have been way too many times where I'll have a range of 1-50 and the CPU will have a range of 1-9 and I end up with 8 and CPU gets 9. The RNG is tipped so much in favor of the CPU that I rarely ever try to cause these. Whenever I'm on offense I play it safe and do short passes through open space. This can easily be fixed throughout the Early Access so this might change. 2. As great as it is to see the team I follow in MLS in this game, I wish the players that were on the team in real life were in this game. I completely understand that this game doesn't have the license from MLS but they could still put similar names and similar attributes to the players. Small issue in the end but it'd be a nice addition.3. The game gives you three turns to move but I rarely find that it's enough. Occasionally you'll get lucky and the stars will allign or the CPU does something dumb and turns the ball over at midfield but most of the time they'll bring the ball to your box, miss and then youll spend three turns passing it up tp your forward when your turn ends. I understand that this could be to emulate how soccer games can be: two teams running the ball back and forth but the way it is now makes the game feel choppy instead of realistic. I think the best way to handle this since soccer is a game that's very much about movement is to borrow the turn based mode from XCOM: EU and have two actions per "turn" for the three players you choose. For example, using a through ball isn't possible unless your player has a certain trait learned which can take up to a full season to learn and it can only be used once a game. If the XCOM turn based mode was introduced you could have one guy run ad midfield and pass while  a striker ran to meet the ball and one time it at goal. The RNG really kills it for me bcause I haven't experience some of the one on one combat due to the high chance that my team will lose and concede a goal. As it stands, I can't reccommend the game right now. It feels like the goal was to make a simpler Football Manager 16 while also being more nuanced than the FIFA 16 Manager mode but IMO the game is an acrade game that relies too much on chance. I hope some of my issues are fixed because this has the potential to suck days of my life if I feel like my preperation of my team has an effect on the one on one duals.

								The Skinny: Good polish to an interesting concept tagged and labeled as a genre bending tactical/strategy/rpg/sports simulation game. Confusing design decisions caused this title to suffer an identiy crisis deciding if it was going to be a casual or hardcore. Worse still the developers failed to circumvent some of the pitfalls that come with combining so many concepts together.Even More Skinny: This game feels alot like a very polished mobile phone freemium game without the microtransactions.I do of course approve of the developers excluding the microtransactions and the care they have taken in refining their product to be presented in a a concise and easy-to-use package.The Longer View:Tough game to pin down and fit into a Box but I will give it a shot...I would say this game is a Sports Simulation first and then a Strategy game consisting of some Turn-based RPG elements with a strong Tactical component. Conceptually it seems like an excellent foundation from which you could start building a very unique and deep game but I did not find there to be much complexity to any of the mechanics that were built on top of that great foundation. To me the concept of the game suggests and hints that this is going to be a hardcore crowd pleaser. However, from a presentation standpoint the UI, graphic design, and simplistic text descriptions of events/outcomes/etc. are all much more in line with a casual gaming experience usually found on a mobile phone or facebook game.  I can honestly say that I enjoy both casual phone games (the higher quality ones at least) and hardcore pc games. I will also say that all of the genre's I mentioned earlier are favorites of mine. but I feel that this game comes up short in the areas that usually make each of those genres fun and appealing.I Liked:Unique ConceptPlayer agency in chosing between a few different methods to build your squadTactics (I personally am going to buy your game if this is in the title and the screenshots/playthroughs/video is anything short of atrocious)RPG Elements blended with the Sports SimulatorUI and controls are streamlined perfectly (really well done)No MicrotransactionsAC/DC:Predomintly a Casual GameMedium-to-High RNG elementsGrindySound Effects/Music - I would say this aspect was OK but also somewhat sparse and repetitive (I play most sim games listening to a soundtrack of my own choosing anyway)But awwwwww C'mon:4 attributes are just not enough.....unless you have an excellent system of Special Abilites to compliment them...Special Abilities are a bit vanilla and many of the defensive ones pointlessNo real storyline feel and very limited options for customizations to "create your own"Small size of the playing field grid limits optionsVery Limited Defensive OptionsFeels like a Hardcore Gaming Input is required b/c....Progression is slow and incrimentalDifficutly/Balancing Staggered Resulting in Long Periods of cruising followed by getting your face crushed once you've hit a (non-pay) wallJuxtaposition of the two points immediately above this oneThat last point was the real fun killer for me. Football Tactics fails in this regard by setting itself up with a freemium game structure in that you are either struggling to progress because you have not inserted enough currency (in this case time spent grinding) or blowing the competition out of the water because you have. The tactical aspects of games will occasionally allow for you to beat a superior opponent and it is at the moment Football Tactics shines brightest. This too comes with a pitfall unfortunately because of the limited amount of diversity offered in your player builds and to a lesser degree limited number of spaces and therefore movement on the field. The result is that there are a limited number of choices to your strategies and many of them will come down to attempting a similiar set of actions that rely more on maximizing your best chance at a good roll (RNG haters beware) than careful planning. I really felt like I was being punished by the game for succeeding with these tactics early on as it caused my squad to advance up the divisions twice in concurent seasons and left my underfunded squad facing more difficult odds (literally rng odds not tactical difficulties) than any tactical approach would be able to sufficiently overcome. Two comparision points I would like to bring up are the statistical heavy Football Manager Series and Tactical Aspects of Blood Bowl.  In a way I feel like Football Tactics is alot like playing a toned down version of the Football Manager series when your simulating games managing your squad, improving through the transfer windows, or youth player discoveries or in-squad development. The depth of the systems for Football Manager is really what makes it a game worth playing in the first place and again the lack of options present in Football Tactics prevents it from succeeding in the same way. As a Tactical Game Blood Bowl succeeds in the importance of placing your units in the correct spot is crucial because you are making a choice of influencing some control over a large amount of space (by spreading your characters out) or influencing a greater amount of control over a smaller area (keeping your units closer together). Football Tactics gives your units VERY limited influence over space and gives you a very limited field with which to work. When your opponent has the ball most of your units can only influence the space they occupy by being giving a chance to steal the ball if your opponent chooses to challenge that space by dribbling through it or passing almost directly through it. Most of the time this will not factor in as your opponent will choose to forgoe any chance of an interception by making a very safe pass (when a more direct approach is necessary in terms of scoreline/time managment) or simply dribbling past your player. Defenders have the ability to influence shots that cross the spot next to them which is a good start but why do they allow the ball carrier to dribble into that same space without interference? It just does not work for me to have a game labeled as TACTICS and have such a limited number of tactical options.Casual FM with a Turn-based Tactics similiar to Blood Bowl sounded like a sure-fire winning column title in my book but the pace of progression/balancing aspects and strange design choices really drag this one down in the mud. This is still early access stage so things could improve but baring some momnumental shift in the game design and direction I can not see my opinion changing at this point. Would love to be proved wrong here btw. I am really hoping to see a sequel/reboot/clone that adds depth pop up and deliver on the substantial amount of promise I see unfufilled here. Points for UI streamlining and original concept though....3.5/10

Early Access Review
								**Revised review March 5, 2016**The latest version of Football Tactics, as of this review, has converted my original vote of no to a yes. However, the part that swayed me is an optional setting, so please note that the default game still seems too random. So long as you go into it with reasonable expectations, Football Tactics can be quite charming.For one thing, it features slick design and UI. Information is easily accessible with a few clicks, and managing positions and rosters is straightforward.  This ties into the streamlined managerial experience. People who want a lot of number crunching and projections can play Football Manager.  This game is more arcade-like, with a simplified simulation.  You still get the whole experience (signing, training, budgeting, seasons, tournaments, etc.), but it's bite-sized.The matches play in a similar fashion to blitzball in Final Fantasy X: players have four stats that determine their passing, shooting, defensive, and positional abilities.  There are also "skills" that allow them to make harder shots, longer passes, etc. It is turn based, and each game consists of 48 actions taken in threes.  Success is determined by rolling one's players stat versus the opposition's stat.  For example, a player with a Pass rating of 24 is attempting to pass through an opponent with a Defense stat of 12.  Both players generate a random number from 1 to x, where x is their stat; the higher number prevails (ties go to the active team).In the default settings, the RNG has too much variability for my taste, and they can significantly reduce the effectiveness of your tactics.  Some games devolve into a matter of who rolls better, you or the computer.  Training players takes a lot of time, and acquiring better players is expensive.  Tournaments happen each year, and if you get to enter, you will likely be facing teams from much higher leagues.  Their stats will be significantly higher than yours, and you will only be able to hope for a tie.There is a new, optional setting when creating a new game that gives players a skill floor of 30% of their rating.  This means that high-skilled players can more consistently outclass weaker opponents, although they can still be beaten.  Although I would prefer that this setting be integrated into the core game, its presence makes it easier to execute tactics consistently rather than gambling on a lucky roll.
